bioghist.p: William Wagner (1796-1885) was a philanthropist and naturalist. At the age of 16, he was apprenticed to the financier Stephen Girard. In 1816 he was sent as an assistant supercargo on a two-year trading voyage, during which he collected many shell, plant, and fossil specimens. After leaving Girard's employ, he went into business as a shipping merchant with Charles A. Snowden. This partnership was dissolved in 1825, and Wagner continued as a merchant in his own firm. He retired from business in 1840. In 1847, he began to deliver lectures on scientific topics, and, finding that interest in these lectures was strong, founded the Wagner Free Institute of Science in 1855.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of four travel journals kept by William Wagner during his two year honeymoon in Europe with his wife Louisa Binney Wagner. Volume 1 contains entries for travel from Philadelphia to London and Manchester; volume 2 contains material on Manchester, Dublin, Belfast, Hamburg, Berlin, Leipzig, and Dresden; volume 3 covers Prague, Vienna, Trieste, Greece, Rome, and Pompeii; and volume 4 contains entries for Florence, Leghorn, Geneva, Milan, Como, Zurich, Basel, Manheim, Strasbourg, and Paris. In the diaries Wagner describes his daily activities as well as various European sights and monuments in extensive detail. He also describes visits and conversations relating to the development of his collections. Volume 3 contains several loose and tipped in sketches of architectural features, boxes, and furniture, as well as a color drawing based on an artist's rendition of the eruption of Mount Etna. Two loose items from a later period are in the back of volume 4: an exchange agreement from the Academie Imperiale de Metz from 1857 and a short Philadelphia Inquirer article about the Wagner Free Institute of Science from 1955.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found in the following collections: Wagner Free Institute of Science: the Robert Chambers collection (90-015) (Box 5, folder 61) contains a series of letters of introduction given to William Wagner for his honeymoon trip to Europe in 1841-1842. The William Wagner personal papers (89-010) contains Wagner's handwritten lists that mention contacts for fossils in Europe.
